fields.description:
Recently I've seen a few situations whereby users are trying to launch instances on an NC which has VT disabled in the BIOS.  To try and stop users even getting to this point I think it might be sensible if we print a warning on NC service start by doing some basic checks for CPU virt extensions and VT enablement in the BIOS.

I'd like to propose that the eucalyptus-nc.in script has the following lines after setting up the environment variables in do_start():

{code}
# Basic check for VT, warning if we think its not enabled in BIOS

# First, lets check CPU flags to see if we have hardware support 

HYPERVISOR=$(grep ^HYPERVISOR ${EUCALYPTUS}/etc/eucalyptus/eucalyptus.conf | cut -d'"' -f 2)  <-- or borrow this variable
CPU_MODEL=$(egrep -m1 -w '^flags[[:blank:]]*:' /proc/cpuinfo | egrep -wo '(vmx|svm)')

# Be heavy-handed, exit with failure on lack of CPU virtualization support.

egrep -m1 -w '^flags[[:blank:]]*:' /proc/cpuinfo | egrep -wo '(vmx|svm)')
if [ $? -ne 0 ] ; then 
         echo "Terminating! This Node Controller does not have CPU virtualization support, you will not be able to run instances."
         exit 1
fi

# Now we check to see if it's enabled in BIOS by loading the kvm modules. Warn rather than exit and suggest the user enables this. 

# For Intel systems

if [ $CPU_MODEL == vmx -a $HYPERVISOR == kvm ] ; then
        modprobe kvm_intel
                if [ $? -ne 0 ] ; then
                        echo "Unable to load KVM module, VT-x may be disabled in your systems BIOS, please enable it. You will not be able to launch instances."
                fi
fi

# For AMD systems

if [ $CPU_MODEL == svm -a $HYPERVISOR == kvm ] ; then
        modprobe kvm_amd
                if [ $? -ne 0 ] ; then
                        echo "Unable to load KVM module, AMD-V may be disabled in your systems BIOS, please enable it. You will not be able to launch instances."
                fi
fi

{code}
fields.summary: Check for VT enablement in BIOS at NC service start

comments.body: Made some edits to the quick n dirty script I put in this ticket.
Having actually looked at the init script now, looks like we'll also need a fault code to pass to euca-generate-fault.

this is a good place (eucalyptus-nc.in); another candidate would be in the euca_test_nc program, which is executed just prior to starting an NC to ensure that the environment is ready to use as an NC.  The benefit of the euca_test_nc spot is that one could use the new fault mechanism to log a formatted fault in this case.

Lester,

Seems like we have a couple of places where the fix can be placed.  You mind putting the pull request in, then we can get it assigned to an Engineer for review.  Thanks again for bringing this up.  Let me know if there are any questions.

Cheers,

Harold Spencer, Jr.

Sure, will get this done this week.

Thanks folks.

p.s I'll probably go for the init script, my reasoning here is that we want to warn or block before a user tries to launch instances on their NC.  This will be helpful for lots of reasons, hopefully it is a useful notice to the user and also it might help cut down on some support tickets :)
Assigning to Lester.  He plans to add in a patch for this improvement.
Finally got back around to this, added a fault so that it ends up in euca-fault.log on the NC.  I'll submit this PR on Monday after I briefly test it.
[~dmitrii], can you add this in (or review) please?   [~agrimm], let me know if there's anything else I can do to get this into 3.3
Sorry, who was "Anonymous" who marked this as fixed? cc [~shaon] [~graziano]
[~tjcramer], [~dmitrii], was this close accidentally? There was no comments about the resolution.

[~graziano], [~lwade], no idea how this was closed.  I don't know how "anonymous" was able to do this.  Probably not logged in and a public ticket.
We'll fix that.

However, this pull request should still be reviewed and resolved.
[~dmitrii] ?

Not sure why this was closed. Wasn't me, I swear! But I _will_ take responsibility for sitting on the pull request for a long time. I got swamped and forgot about it, sorry.

The good news is, the commit is now in 3.3.1 and in 3.4 branches. Apparently I didn't do everything right because github doesn't recognize the pull request as closed (perhaps my cherry-picking caused commit IDs to change). But, most importantly, the stuff is in the code:

* 3.3.1
** https://github.com/eucalyptus/eucalyptus/commit/e4e783f37011775e365e4db9faa7a12789574633
** https://github.com/eucalyptus/eucalyptus/commit/5ad149b1cf93cfc1a0c44eab4bd667c6a883efe7
* 3.4
** https://github.com/eucalyptus/eucalyptus/commit/935e92f628bdb41014107b7ebe6e45dffb4638b3
** https://github.com/eucalyptus/eucalyptus/commit/9fb3f38e5e99dedd19a309f5b21743ee81c1dd9c

Thank you for the contribution, Lester! This is a great thing to check for on the NC.
Not sure how this got reopened.
